title: Image Fusion for Cross-Domain Sequential Recommendation
author: Wangyu Wu (Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University, The University of Liverpool), Xiaowei Huang (The University of Liverpool), Siqi Song (Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University, The University of Liverpool), Fei Ma (Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University), Xianglin Qiu (Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University, The University of Liverpool), Jimin Xiao (Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University), ...
relevance_why: The integration of visual data with sequential recommendations could enhance audio-visual data alignment tasks, potentially benefiting applications in music recommendation and audio generation.
background: Cross-Domain Sequential Recommendation (CDSR) involves predicting future user actions based on past interactions across different domains, utilizing both item features and visual data.
contribution: This paper introduces the IFCDSR method, which incorporates image features into traditional sequential recommendation systems to enhance item representation and recommendation accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous CDSR methods often focused solely on text-based item features, neglecting visual input which can significantly influence user preferences.
technical_comparison.novelty: The proposed method improves by integrating CLIP-derived image embeddings with traditional item ID embeddings, allowing for a richer representation of user preferences.

key_innovation: Combines image-based and ID-based features through multiple attention mechanisms to accurately capture user preferences across domains.
real_world_impact: This approach has significant implications for recommender systems in e-commerce and media platforms, enhancing user experience by providing more personalized content suggestions based on both visual and textual information.
limitations: The paper does not discuss potential limitations regarding the scalability of the model or its adaptability to other domains.

new_terms.CDSR: **Cross-Domain Sequential Recommendation** refers to recommendation systems that utilize data and interactions across different domains to make predictions, improving personalization and accuracy.
new_terms.CLIP: **Contrastive Language–Image Pre-training** is a model developed by OpenAI that learns visual concepts from natural language descriptions, allowing for a rich understanding of images in relation to text.
